news four-ways-make-your-christmas-"Coronavirus in numbers: UK records , new casesAdvertorialByNatasha YoungCommercial Audience Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Jan Those long-awaited Christmas get-togethers with family and friends are just around the corner, but with the highly transmissible Omicron iant spreading fast it’s important to take some extra steps to make your celebrations Covid-safe. Close contact with others – especially in unventilated spaces – increases your chances of spreading Covid-. If you’re spending the festive season with loved ones there are lots of ways you can reduce the risk, including taking regular rapid lateral flow tests, letting fresh air in and getting your booster. GP Dr Claire Ashley provides some simple tips for staying safe so you and those close to you can gather round the table and enjoy your Christmas fun. Take those tests  Meeting up with loved ones  You should all do a rapid lateral flow test before you mingle.They’re free, easy to do at home and the results show in half an hour – to order a pack, go to nhs.uk get-tested.“If you haven’t got any symptoms, rapid lateral flow tests are very good at picking up Covid-,” says Dr Ashley, based in the South West. “On Christmas morning, before granny comes over for lunch, taking a test is the best way to check you’re not infectious. “My family will all have a rapid lateral flow test the morning we travel down to see my parents, andanything comes back positive, or any of us has symptoms, we won’t go. “I’m aware our plans might be disrupted. It’s not perfect, especially after last year, but I’d rather everyone stays safe.”  As Dr Ashley points out, rapid lateral flow tests are designed to pick up Covid- cases with no symptoms, soyou do have symptoms such as a fever, cough or loss of sense of taste or smell, you need to isolate immediately and take a PCR test. Andyour rapid lateral flow test does show a positive result, you’ll need to isolate and only leave the house to take a PCR test to confirm it.If you have been in contact with someone with Covid- and are double vaccinated, you should take a daily rapid lateral flow test for seven daysyou have no symptoms. If you test positive or develop symptoms in those seven days, you must self-isolate, take a PCR test and follow the guidance on gov.uk.If you are unvaccinated, you must self-isolate for  daysyou are in contact with someone who has Covid-.Don’t forget the NHS COVID- app is still the fastest way to knowyou’ve been exposed to someone who’s tested positive, so keep it on.Open the window sLetting fresh air into your home is one way to help reduce the spread of Covid-. Opening windows and doors for just  minutes will help. “Covid- is an airborne virus and the research suggests that when you’re in a well-ventilated space the risk of contracting it is reduced,” says Dr Ashley. “That’s why being outdoors is much more safe, but that’s tricky when it’s very cold. Soyou want to reduce the chances of Covid- being passed on, have the windows open so you get as much airflow as possible.” Wear a face covering You must wear a face covering in public areas such as shops, places of worship, entertainment venues, and on public transport. It’s wise to wear a mask in crowded or enclosed spaces, eventhey’re not legally required. “Face coverings are really effective at reducing how much you’re spreading Covid-,” explains Dr Ashley. Get your booster Every adult in the country now needs to get a Covid- booster vaccine, because two doses does not give you enough protection against catching Omicron. Book yours now at nhs.uk covidvaccination.Get Boosted Now is the national mission to build a wall of defence against the Omicron iant. This mission is more urgent than ever before with Covid- because Omicron is spreading fast. Vaccines are the best way we can protect ourselves. You can get a Covid- booster  weeks after your second dose. Boosters give you the best possible protection against the virus and should signicantly reduce your risk of serious illness and hospitalisation.If you haven’t had your first or second vaccine, go to nhs.uk covidvaccination or call  to book it, or find your nearest walk-in centre.“It’s also very important for pregnant women to get vaccinated,” adds Dr Ashley. “The benefits of being vaccinated and boosted really outweigh the risks.”People with lower immune systems might need to be more careful about socialising this Christmas, as they could have less protection against getting severely ill with Covid-. This includes people who are taking medication that suppresses the immune system – eg, for rheumatoid arthritis – and those having chemotherapy. For more advice on celebrating the festive season safely, visit: gov.uk coronavirus Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CoronavirusMost ReadRecommended

title: labour mp jack dromeys incredible
story: Labour MP Jack Dromeys incredible le and famous MP we following sudden deathLabour MP Jack Dromey passed away on Friday morning and tributes have poured in since his death. The Birmingham Erdington MP was married to fellow MP Harriet HarmanJack Dromey held essential roles at the heart of Labour and worked as a trade unionist for many years Image: RexByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan | commentsLabour MP for Birmingham Erdington Jack Dromey passed away on Friday at the age of .He began representing the long-considered safe Labour seat in  and secured a majority of , in . Dromey, along with fellow MP and we Harriet Harman, was a well-known figure in the House of Commons.Labour leader Keir Starmer said: The proud son of Irish parents, Jack Dromey dedicated his le to standing up for working people through the Labour movement, becoming Deputy General Secretary of the UK’s largest trade union and then a Labour MP.One of the ministeraposs final acts as an MP was to participate in the debate on the resettlement of Afghan refugees only a day before his death. Jack was recognised for his determination to stand up for his constituents and he was highly respected and warmly regarded across Parliament, said Starmer My thoughts and those of the whole Labour movement are with Harriet, their children and all those who knew and loved Jack. Who was MP Jack Dromey   Born in , Jack Dromey was an MP for the Birmingham Erdington constituency, first elected in . Before being elected as an MP, Dromey was an old school Labourite, working as a trade unionist. He held a senior role as Deputy General Secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, which later became known as Unite.  Dromey held a range of shadow ministerial positions, such as Shadow Minister for Housing, as well as policing, labour, pensions and paymaster general. The latest reshuffle by Labour leader Keir Stamer saw Dromey move to Shadow Minister for Immigration. Deputy Labour leader Angela Rayner said: Jack Dromey was a great mentor and supporter to me but above all a friend for many years. This is absolutely tragic news for his family, his constituents and the party. I am thinking of Harriet and the rest of his family. He will be greatly missed.What did Jack Dromey die of Labour MP Jack Dromey is understood to have passed away from natural causes. His son Joe tweeted: Our dad - Jack - died suddenly today. We loved him so, so much. Rest in peace big man x.  A statement issued on behalf of the family said: He had been a dedicated member of parliament for Birmingham Erdington since . He was a much loved husband, father and grandfather, and he will be greatly missed. Jack Dromeyaposs family  The Birmingham Erdington MP is survived by his we and fellow MP Harriet Harman and their three children, Harry, Joseph and Amy.Harman announced last month that she would be standing down at the next election.The MP for Camberwell and Peckham is one of the Labour partyaposs most recognisable faces, serving as deputy leader between  to  and is the Commonsapos recognised Mother of the House.  The two are reported to have met in  on the picket line for the strike by workers of the Grunwick film processing laboratory in London. The pair then married in . Grunwick strikers were mainly workers of South Asian origin and became signicant as a landmark strike that brought attention to ethnic minority workers in the UK.Dromey wrote about the importance of the strike for the Mirror in .Jack Dromey is survived by his we Harriet, sons Harry and Joe and daughter Amy. title: liz truss accused hiding truth
story: Exclusive: Liz Truss accused of hiding the truth over missing £, food and drink bill in TokyoThe Cabinet minister has been accused of hiding the truth after the Department for International Trade failed to highlight her team splashed more than £, on a three-night tripLiz Truss is now the Foreign Secretary Image: Tayfun Salci ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan | commentsForeign Secretary Liz Truss has been accused of “hiding the truth” as more revelations emerged about her expensive tastes in dining. Ms Truss failed to disclose £,. of public money spent on fancy meals and drinks whilst on a three night trip to Tokyo in . The then-Trade Secretary flew to Japan between - October  to sign Britain’s first post-Brexit trade agreement. After the trip, the Department for International Tradeclaimed her travelling party had spent £. of public money on food and drinks, in response to a Parliamentary Question posed by Labouraposs Emily Thornberry. But two months after Ms Thornberry put in an FOI request, DIT was forced to reveal she had splashed an eye-watering £,. whilst away with three officials. Last night foreign office sources suggested that Ms Truss and her team had not been able to leave her accommodation as a result of Covid rules in Tokyo. But they were unable to say how they had accrued the expenses, or whether they stayed in a hotel with its own bars and restaurants.  Shadow Attorney General Ms Thornberry told the Mirror: “There is a clear pattern of behaviour emerging here with Liz Truss, which raises serious questions about her character. “Becauseher instinct is to hide the truth and hope that no one asks questions even over these expenses claims, what  is she willing to do that about ” It is not the first time Ms Trussapos department has failed to correctly disclose the correct amount of public money she has spent on fancy meals. After her visit to Japan, Ms Truss spent four nights in Vietnam and Singapore to sign more post-Brexit trade deals with four members of staff. The DIT initially claimed Ms Trussaposs travelling party had not spent anything on meals and drinks. But then Trade Minister Greg Hands was forced to reveal the travelling party had actually splashed £,, the equivalent of £, per head, or £ per night.  But then Trade Minister Greg Hands was forced to reveal the travelling party had actually splashed £,, the equivalent of £, per head, or £ per night. Mr Hands also revealed Ms Truss’s travelling party spent an eye-watering £,. on accommodation in addition to the meals. “How did they go from saying there were no subsistence expenses at all, to saying the travelling party incurred expenses of £, per head, equivalent to £ per night ” Ms Thornberry questioned.It comes days after it was revealed Ms Truss hosted a lunch at an expensive private club owned by a Tory donor, after overruling civil service advice to look for a cheaper venue. Leaked correspondence, first published in the Sunday Times, revealed the ex-Trade secretary “refused to consider anywhere” but  Hertford Street for a meeting with Joe Biden ’s trade representative in August last year.Ms Truss is reported to have previously used the  Hertford Street club to host “fizz with Lizz” dinners with MPs and “biz for Liz” receptions with potential donors, in preparation for a likely leadership bid.The club is considered to be London’s most exclusive club, having hosted Prince Harry ’s first date with Meghan. Ms Truss is widely seen as a favourite to become Prime MinisterBoris Johnson is ousted.The government was contacted for comment. title: the divide between entitled rich
story: The ide between the entitled rich and the rest of us is now gaping chasmBrian Reade laments that the separation between the classes in Britain is greater than its ever beenGhislaine Maxwell is facing a long stint behind bars Image: Getty ImagesopinionByBrian Reade:,  Jan For deluded fools who believe they might be in for a prosperous year, here’s some advice.Ring up The Chase or put your grandad’s pocket watch on eBay because with the energy and tax rises coming down the line there’s a good chance you’ll be humming Buddy Can You Spare A Dime  by Easter.Some will hum a dferent tune, of course. Major shareholders in the energy firms will amass billions out of rising prices and the NI tax hike won’t hurt too many millionaire Cabinet ministers or company bosses. In fact, according to the High Pay Centre, by am today the average chief executive of a FTSE  company had already been paid the average British worker’s salary for . And he’s probably still skiing in the Alps. There’s always been a gap between the rich and the rest, but it feels like it’s becoming a chasm. And the main dference between the top % and everyone  is their expectation to be treated dferently.  Think back to the Mirror’s revelations of how Downing Street held festive knees-ups after barring the rest of us from having a cuppa with a lonely old relative. They were angered that it was even a story – as though it was a given that they were free to act dferently. Look at the Establishment attitude to the loaded heiress Ghislaine Maxwell being convicted of facilitating and participating in the sexual abuse of children. Her brother went on BBC Radio’s Today show to denigrate the jury’s verdict and tug on our heartstrings. Others sought to evoke sympathy for her by writing in newspapers about this charming woman who had been manipulated by the monster Jeffrey Epstein. If the paedophile-enabler had been a single mum on benefits, not a well-connected socialite, what are the chances of the BBC inviting her brother on to its flagship news show to plead her innocence  In the same case, we’ve seen Prince Andrew’s lawyers attempt to hide behind a silencing deal between Epstein and the woman who accuses him of sexual abuseto escape answering questions. And his family goes along with this stonewalling without being called out. Well they’re royal, ain’t they  Which brings us to the honours they dish out, most of which are bought. Sure, little people are thrown the odd bangle to disguise the charade, but the major gongs are status symbols the amoral rich seek out to show they are a cut above the rest. Last week, I named -year-old Folajimi Olubunmi-Adewole, who died in the Thames trying to rescue a drowning woman, as my Man of the Year. He didn’t make the New Year’s Honours list.  Tony Blair was knighted though, despite the Chilcot report stating he knowingly misled the country into a war which cost the lives of hundreds of thousands of Iraqis and  Britons. A petition to cancel his knighthood is climbing towards the one million that marched through London begging him to rethink his illegal invasion. But the man who has now made £million since leaving office will once again ignore it because that’s what the very rich do. That’s the power their wealth has bought. Chew on that in a couple of months when people you know are choosing whether to go further into debt with Scottish Power, or eat. title: tory minister says molly mae
story: Tory minister says Molly-Mae Hagues tone deaf success comments are fairSmall Business Minister Paul Scully backed the Love Island star, saying aspiration was no bad thingThe reality star has been slammed for her tone deaf comments Image: YoutubeByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA Tory minister has defended ex-Love Islander Molly-Mae Hague over her tone deaf comments over wealth inequality.The -year-old influencer, who has won lucrative endorsement deals since appearing on the reality show in , sparked a backlash over for saying she deserved her success as she had worked my absolute a*** off and we all have the same  hours.But Small Business Minister Paul Scully weighed in on the row, saying an aspirational approach to le is no bad thing.Molly-Mae, who boasts . million Instagram followers and . million YouTube subscribers, made the comments in YouTube series aposDiary of a CEOapos which aired in December.In the clip which went viral this week, she said: Youaposre given one le and itaposs down to you what you do with it. You can literally go in any direction.  aposWhen Iaposve spoken about that in the past I have been slammed a little bit, with people saying itaposs easy for you to say that because youaposve not grown up in poverty, so for you to sit there and say we all have the same  hours in a day is not correct. But, technically, what Iaposm saying is correct. We do. She went on: “I understand we all have dferent backgrounds and we’re all raised in dferent ways and we do have dferent financial situations, but I thinkyou want something enough you can achieve it. “It just depends on what s you want to go to get where you want to be in the future. And I’ll go to any .” She then added: “I’ve worked my absolute a*** off to get where I am now.” The comments were branded tone deaf on social media, with critics saying many hard-working Brits are struggling to make ends meet amid a cost of living crunch. She released a statement on Friday defending her comments, saying she was not commenting on anyone ’s le or personal situation she can only speak of her own experience. But Molly-Mae found an unlikely ally in Tory Minister Paul Scully.  Askedher comments were fair, Mr Scully told LBC: I think it is, but I think youaposve got to define success, because some of the comments that I was hearing in the lead up to my piece on this was about money, but success doesnapost necessarily equal money. It can be, you know, furthering your job, whether itaposs in public service or whatever. And I think an aspirational approach to le is no bad thing. What weaposve got to make sure, though, is that opportunity is equally distributed around the country. And thataposs why the levelling up agenda that we often talk about in government is so, so important to make sure that those  hours can be matched by the opportunities by education and business across the country. A spokesman for the Prime Minister said he had not discussed Molly-Maeaposs comments with Boris Johnson. In a statement, a representative for Molly-Mae said she had been referring to a quote that inspires her which states aposWe all have the same  hours in a day as Beyonceapos. Her opinion onyou want something enough you can work hard to achieve it is how she keeps determined with her own work to achieve more in her own le, the statement said. Molly is not commenting on anyone ’s le or personal situation she can only speak of her own experience. Her representative added: Social media users have shared a short snippet from this interview with words such as apos you are homeless buy a houseapos and apos you are poor be poorapos these are absolutely not Molly’s words, these are not Molly’s thoughts and this isn’t at all the meaning or thought behind that conversation. title: uk oil gas giants raked
story: Exclusive: UK oil and gas giants raked in £BILLION in just THREE months as energy bills soarShell and BP reported the combined profits, idends and buybacks just as wholesale gas prices began to soar. The two firms have had £million in tax credits in the last five yearsShell and BP raked in £.billion in just three months last year Image: Stuart W ConwayByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Jan | commentsThe UK’s biggest oil and gas companies raked in £.billion in just three months last year, figures reveal. Shell and BP reported the combined profits, idends and buybacks just as wholesale gas prices began to soar.Households face an increase of up to £, in dual fuel bills from April when the energy price cap is reviewed. The two firms have had £million in tax credits in the last five years, according to official figures. It was also reported last autumn they paid zero UK tax on North Sea gas and oil for three years. BP chief executive Bernard Looney boasted it was a “cash machine” after soaring prices boosted profits.  In March it was reported Mr Looney would receive £.m for the year, while it was revealed in the spring that Shell chief Ben van Beurden’s  pay was €.m . The Government is planning to bring in new measures to help with energy bills. Ministers are believed to be considering bringing in a windfall tax, extending the £-a-year Warm Home Discount or removing green levies.PM Boris Johnson is resisting calls to slash the % VAT on dual fuel. From July to September, Shell and BP reported combined profits, idends and buybacks of £.bn. This included profits of .bn, around £.bn. Profits were up from just over bnin the same quarter in . Another .bnin Shell buybacks were completed, with BP announcing a further .bn . A buyback is a firm buying back its own shares to increase their price. Between them, the firms paid out .bnin idends over the three-month period.  Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Pat McFadden said: “These figures will stick in the throat of working people.” The Lib Dems said a windfall tax would offer families a £bn winter leline. Leader Ed Davey said: “It can’t be right that a few fat cats are raking it in.” The firms claim they did not pay corporate income tax because of tax losses arising in the current and previous years. Shell said it had stepped in to help customers of failed energy firms. BP did not comment.The RAC accused fuel retailers of not passing on lower wholesale petrol prices, saying they should have dropped “nearer to p” a litre in December instead of the average of .p.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPat McFaddenThe TreasuryBPEnergyPetrol pricesTaxEnergy billsGas pricesPoliticsBenefitsTax CreditsDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: flirty instagram comment led love
story: Flirty Instagram comment led to love - but we couldnt speak the same languageBradley Alcock, , started chatting to Samantha Garcia, , after she left a cheeky comment under one of his Instagram posts - and they refused to let a language barrier get in the wayBradley proposed to Samantha while on holiday in Paignton, Devon Image: Bradley AlcockByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsWhen Bradley Alcock received a comment on his Instagram photo calling him “handsome” he was flattered - but thought little more of it. The flirty comment had been left underneath his photo by -year-old Samatha Garcia, who Bradley had followed for some time. But living , miles apart, Bradley, from Coventry and Samantha, from Mexico, had never met. “A few days after she commented on my photo, I sent Samantha a message and said hello,” Bradley, , told The Mirror. The pair started chatting and realised there was a spark between them. There was just one problem - neither of them spoke the same language. While the pair chatted in Spanish, Bradley, who works night shts in a supermarket, was using online translator tools to try and communicate with Samantha. Still, the language barrier didn’t stop them. “We usually spoke every day and our relationship just grew,” Bradley explained. “After about a month of texting we had our first video call.”For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Although he loved speaking to his beau on video, Bradley was still using translation tools to communicate with Samantha in Spanish. He said: “We knew it would be easierwe could speak more naturally. I’ve always liked Spanish and Samantha gave me the motivation to actually learn.” Determined to break down the language barrier, he hired a Spanish tutor and joined language learning website Duolingo in October . From then on, he used Duolingo almost every day and saw his tutor whenever he could. “I used it every day for  or  minutes,” he said, adding he fit sessions in around his shts at work. And as time passed, his vocabulary started to improve. But when the pandemic hit and his tutor moved back to Spain, Bradley relied solely on the website to improve his language skills.  And lockdown put the brakes on another of Bradley’s plans - a trip to Mexico to meet Samantha in person. “We planned everything for April , but obviously it got cancelled,” he recalled. “I booked the trip again for October, and luckily it went ahead.” After more than a year of speaking online every single day, Bradley and Samantha finally met in the flesh when his flight landed in Mexico City. “It was amazing,” he said. “From the minute I stepped off the plane and went through the doors of the airport, I was excited.” And luckily, the pair got on just as well in person as they had online. “We were both really nervous for the first few hours, but after that we connected like normal.” For the next three weeks, the pair travelled around Mexico where Bradley could practice his Spanish - and his skills were put to the test when he met Samantha’s family.  “They were lovely. We were constantly at her house speaking to them and watching TV. They were really nice to me,” Bradley said. After three weeks of bliss Bradley had to leave his beau and fly back to the UK - which was more dficult than he’d anticipated. “It was horrible. Being at the airport and saying goodbye was awful,” he said.So as soon as he was back on UK soil, Bradley started planning Samantha’s visit to the UK as soon as they could - but more coronavirus restrictions got in the way.“We planned for her to come for five months so she could live with me and get to know England properly,” he said.  After nearly six months apart, Samantha arrived in London in April , where Bradley was eagerly waiting to collect her. And, once they had both been grilled about Samantha’s visit by border force officials, Samantha and Bradley were finally reunited. For the next few months, Bradley showed Samantha around the sights of the UK, and in August he took her on a caravan trip to Paignton in Devon - where he popped the question in a park filled with flowers. “I’d been planning it for a couple of months but I was just trying to find the right time and place,” he said. The newly-engaged pair spent another month together until Samantha had tohome to Mexico in September. Now, the supermarket worker is planning his next trip to Mexico in Spring - when he plans to tie the knot with his beau.Did you meet the love of your le in an unusual way  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc with your storiesBut, even with , miles between them, Bradley’s determination to keep learning Spanish hasn’t waned - and he still logs on for Spanish lessons every day. He joked: “I still get a badge for my achievements every month.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Love" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum given five years live
story: Mum given five years to live finally gets married - nine years after diagnosisChristine Palfrey, , thought she had an abscess in her gum when she suffered from unbearable jaw pain in  - but after seeing a specialist and having tests, she received a shocking diagnosisChristine has tied the knot  years after being told her cancer was incurable Image: Collect PA Real LeByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman given five years to live after being diagnosed with incurable cancer that was eating her jaw has tied the knot with the love of her le - nine years later. Christine Palfrey, , started to feel lethargic in  but assumed she was exercising too much for the amount she was eating. “I was working long hours and feeling tired all the time, but I just pushed through,” she said. But one Sunday in December that year, she woke up with an excruciating pain in her lower jaw. The ex-dental nurse made an emergency appointment to see a dentist - thinking some food had probably got trapped in her gums. But after having X rays, Christine said her dentist went silent. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here He said it could be an abscess, but he didn’t want to speculate and said he would refer me to a specialist in the next couple of days which, of course, set off alarm bells, she recalled. But, knowing plenty about dentistry from her old job, Christine knew it was more serious. An abscess builds, so you don’t get sudden pain, she said. However, she could never have predicted the diagnosis she would soon receive. The dentist referred Christine to a specialist at Kingaposs College Hospital in London, Dr Kathleen Fan. After cutting into her gum, Dr Fan found a solid lump - confirming Christine didnapost have an abscess. She took a biopsy of the lump and sent the mum-of-one home to Bamford, Oxfordshire, to wait for the results.  Then Christine received a letter telling her to come back to the hospital - and bring her then-husband along, too. She recalled: The doctor had the results of the biopsy and said, aposThis is quite a tough one to tell you. You have a very rare form of cancer. I’m afraid it’s not benign.apos Christine was diagnosed with Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma , a rare, aggressive cancer that is usually found in the glands and the head. After her diagnosis, Christine was referred to another specialist in London who told her she needed an operation to remove some of the cancer. But although there were things they could do to treat the cancer, the specialist warned Christine it was stage  and incurable. She was given three to five years to live. Devastated by the news, Christine went ahead with the -hour operation the following week to give herself the best possible chance of survival. The surgery involved talking a section of bone from her left hip to replace the section of her jawbone, which was cut away to remove the cancer. It meant Christine had to learn to walk and talk again, and permanently changed the shape of her face. But the most dficult thing of all was breaking the news to her daughter Victoria, who was just a teenager at the time. “Everyone was crying, but I just kept telling Victoria, aposYou know how strong your mother is. She will get through this. We all will. I will still be me and this is just a bump in the road, so we just need to focus on the futureapos, she recalled.  After the operation, Christine had to undergo radiotherapy for a year, which took its toll on her body. And the strain of cancer also took its toll on her marriage to Victoriaaposs father - with the pair filing for orce in . However, the pair remained on good terms and amicably co-parented Victoria while Christine continued with cancer treatment. Over the years, Christine has had three more operations to remove secondary cancer on her lungs, but sheaposs continued working her office job throughout cancer treatment. And it was in the office she met Barry Weeks, who she at first thought was a bit of an idiot. However, after the pair were sat on desks next to each other, they bonded over a shared silly sense of humour and eventually fell in love. On Christineaposs nd birthday, Barry popped the question, and the pair walked down the aisle in November last year. Given away by her brother Tony and with Victoria, now , by her side as a bridesmaid, Christine said it was a perfect day. Now, sheaposs excited for what the future holds with her new husband and wonapost let cancer stop her from living le to the fullest. “At the moment, I am in a good place and there are no more secondaries.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc“I have my next scan in February, so the base line is that I am not cured but I have been successfully treated.”Christine is now supporting Cancer Research UKaposs Play Your Part campaign, which asks everyone to think about how they can contribute to improving cancer treatments and, eventually, finding a cure.She said: I am following a positive le force and now Barry has given me even more to look forward to in the future, too. title: brits celebrate iconic beach hut
story: Exclusive: Brits celebrate the iconic beach hut - from family treasures to childhood memoriesHeidi Steller, , and her mum Sue, , have spoken of the importance of their beach hut, which is decked in blue and white and is located on Boscombe Beach in BournemouthBeach huts on Mersea Island, Essex Image: Getty ImagesByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Jan | commentsAmong the careworn blue and white crockery in beach hut , there is a pink teacup, older still, which Heidi Steller drinks from every year on June  as she watches the waves. That was her grandmother Angela Noake’s birthday and the teacup was once given to her and husband, Stanley, in , as an engagement gt. This was their beach hut, where the teacup has nestled since they first rented it  years ago, as have the blue and white mats, and the wooden bench Stanley made with a ltable lid to store buckets and spades. It is where their daughter Sue Steller, Heidi’s mum, had birthday parties as a girl where she brought Heidi as a baby to be shaded from the sun, where she “fried her an egg” or rustled up “salad and cold meats” after school for tea.  Where Heidi played with “shells for boats” and later card games like Spite and Malice, cosy against the wind, and where her own three children tottered early steps and now enjoy hot chocolate and pot noodles, boiling the “whistle kettle”. “I always have a tea in that cup with a digestive on her birthday, like she used to,” says Heidi, . “Immediately I get here I feel calmer, things are so much better in the beach hut. I could never, ever give it up.” The hut decked in blue and white, on Boscombe Beach in Bournemouth, which still has the same numbers her grandad carved, is her favourite place in the world. It was her grandmother’s, too, before she died in  aged , many years after her beloved Stanley. “She’d come down on her own to swim, with her lunch - a chunk of cheese, a tomato and a cracker,” smiles Heidi. “It was very much her place.”  Sue, , explains it was a sanctuary for both her parents. This hut, and two they rented before from , along the beach, were the stuff of dreams for Stanley, who was a Prisoner of War in Poland for five years during World War Two. Angela and everyone  thought him dead, while “all he could think about was ‘His Ange’”. They married as soon as they could when he ed in . “After what he went through he dreamt of days on the beach like this,” says Sue. This family’s story of love for their beach hut offers a glimpse of what these tiny, rudimentary sheds mean to us Brits. The passion can be hard to explain abroad, but it was certainly alive and well in Avon Beach, Christchurch, Dorset last Sunday. Dogged locals - and not so locals - queued for up to  hours to secure a beach hut rental there for the summer. Some were up at am to stand in freezing rain to nab a ft x ft box for up to £,. Among some  anoraks zipped tight against the wind, one fan dreaming of a staycation with ready windbreaks and a kettle came from as far as Leicester. In the past, people have travelled from Scotland.  There are approximately , beach huts in the UK. Some are rented, some privately owned. In Bournemouth the waiting list is now shut Heidi explains she was on it for  years in order to take on the rental of their hut from her grandmother in  . Buying a hut is no mean feat. Last July one in nearby Mudeford sold for a staggering £,. That one was a little more deluxe than the norm, but generally the huts are not dissimilar to how they have always been, evolved from the bathing machines on wheels that first carried modest bathers by horse down to the seafront . After WW, councils began providing them for changing and the Victorian and Georgian abandoned machines were regularly converted. Some of the earliest purpose-built examples were erected near Bournemouth Pier in . Today, in the pandemic-forced era of the staycation, they have become hot property. But for Heidi and many more, their huts are more than a roof and windbreaks. They are ingrained in their souls, and house precious memories.  Hilary Knight treasures the beach hut her elderly father built for her in , a year before he died. Harry Bickerton, a carpenter by trade, built the family’s original hut in Eastclf, Walton-On-The-Naze, Essex, in , and enjoyed happy days there with we Phyllis and daughter Hilary until it got swept away in a storm in the late Seventies. “There was nothing left, all the huts were lost,” she says. “There wasn’t a scrap of wood left at all, the sea claimed it all.” In , the family applied to rebuild the hut in the same spot, and Harry, then , erected it in the back garden in sections, to be taken down again and transported to the beach.  “The wood cost around £, but the labour was carried out for love. Every piece of wood inside was planed so there were no sharp corners,” smiles Hilary, . He enjoyed a year there before he died. “Last year beach huts along this stretch were selling for £, but I would not sell it for a million pounds,” she adds. “Every day we would go in the summer, the children say they would never swap our summer holidays. It was the freedom, going down in the early morning, making bacon and eggs. “Now my youngest grandchild brings their paddleboard.”  The Marshes - Southbourne It was the special place she would take her baby Hayley as a newborn and throughout her childhood. One day her little girl would become engaged within its wooden walls. And a few years on, would take her own newborn, Polly, to sleep, gurgle and crawl on the same sandy floor. Sarah Marsh, , adores the beach hut her family have rented in Southbourne, Bournemouth, since , when Hayley, now , was born. Now it holds even more layers of precious memories.  “Hayley’s husband Paddy proposed there in  as it’s Hayley’s favourite place in the world,” she says. “I used to put her down for naps there on a towel, she learnt to swim in the sea, and now she wants Polly to experience the same.” Last summer baby Polly made her first visit aged two weeks. “Our first grandchild loves the hut too,” Sarah smiles. The Coopers - Scarborough Watching families who have never even seen the sea, laugh and play in safety outside her beach hut, is the icing on the cake - or the flake in the ice-cream - for Laura Cooper. The mum-of-three, , bought her Scarborough beach hut on North Bay five years ago, after renting there for . And while long days there with her own sons are a constant pleasure, along with family get-togethers including her hen do, sharing it with others is an extra joy. For the last few years Laura, who runs Scarborough Friends of Refugees, has invited refugee families from Syria, Iran and Afghanistan to enjoy this particularly British pastime.  “It has been an enormous privilege to host beach barbecues for families who have endured the terror of war and faced persecution and atrocity throughout their childhood,” she says. “The simple joy of sharing a barbecue and facilitating play for children, some of whom are seeing the sea for the first time. Language barriers don’t prevent smiles and the delight of children splashing in the waves and digging sandcastles and holes!” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesLoveHen nightDaily MirrorFamily holidays" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couple staying yorkshires most complained
story: Couple staying at Yorkshires most complained about hotel have best time everThe Grand Hotel Scarborough has received a slew of negative reviews in recent years, including from customers who claimed they were unable to stay the night - but some guests have been full of praiseKatie Fox, , and Tony Rewcastle, , visited The Grand on New Years Eve Image: examinerliveByAmber OConnor:,  Jan | commentsA couple who visited a much-complained about Yorkshire hotel which has been labelled a “complete dump” have revealed they were pleasantly surprised by a New Year’s Eve stay.The Grand Hotel Scarborough has received a slew of negative reviews in recent years, including from customers who claimed they were unable to stay the night due to their room being “dirty” and lacking a working door.However, a couple have told how they had the best time ever there, following the hotelaposs recent refurbishment. Katie Fox, , and Tony Rewcastle, , visited The Grand on New Yearaposs Eve after spotting there were rooms available for just £.The pair did not have high expectations after being left unimpressed by a visit during the summer, Katie toldYorkshire Live.But they ended up having a great time, despite only visiting as a joke, according to the holidaymaker. We noticed straight away that they had refurbished, said Katie, who then quipped: Theyaposd got a new carpet. It didnapost smell like an old personaposs home anymore.  And the pair stayed in a new, refurbished room, which Katie thought was a lot better than it was before. She admitted she was surprised to find they had the best time ever. The couple celebrated the evening with a stroll along the beach, where they stopped for fish and chips, before heading back to the hotel to join in the festivities with the other guests. And the fun didnapost stop there. The pair then took to the hotelaposs balcony where they had a perfect birdaposs-eye view of the two firework displays which were set off on the beach. It was absolutely gorgeous, said Katie. She added: And there was a good atmosphere in the lobby. People were having fun they had music on, and there were kids running around with streamers and confetti.  Katie also praised the nice little touches made by staff: Theyaposd put a little chocolate bar in our room, all the hot drinks were in a bag sterilised, there was a little note saying happy new year, and they did free haggis at midnight. She concluded by recommending the hotel to anyone looking for a romantic New Yearaposs Eve, or just hoping to visit Scarborough. Katie said: My opinion of The Grand is they are doing things to change, and we genuinely enjoyed it. It is our go-to place nowwe go back to Scarborough. Previously, the hotel has responded to online critics leaving negative reviews. In response to one complaint, a spokesperson for the hotel said they were truly sorry adding: We hope you raised the concerns at the time giving us the opportunity to get it resolved during your stay. title: first man seek date through
story: First man to seek a date through billboard advert lts the lid on his love leWith a new man going viral this week in his bid to find a we through a billboard ad, the person who first introduced the trend has revealed what happened after his experimentMark Rofe paid £ for a -foot high and -foot wide billboard to find love Image: Jam PressByAlmara Abgarian:,  Jan The first man known to have sought a date through a billboard ad has lted the lid on his love le, revealing that the ad sadly didn’t lead him to true love. With a new man going viral this week in his bid to find a we through a billboard ad, the person who first introduced the trend has revealed what happened after his experiment – and what he thinks of the copycats.In February , Mark Rofe, , from Sheffield, paid £ for a -foot high and -foot wide billboard to find love. Since then, many others have followed in his footsteps. The latest lovelorn fella isMuhammad Malik , , who has erected ads in London and Birmingham with the tongue-in-cheek caption “save me from an arranged marriage”.“There have been several of these types of billboards since I did mine, and I’m sure there will be plenty more to come too,” Mark said. “I’m always happy to see them when they are done for genuine reasons, and Malik’s does appear to be genuine.  It takes balls to do something like this, so I have a lot of respect for that alone. “I hope it works out for him. I am sure there was perhaps some inspiration taken from the billboard I did, andthat is the case when Malik finds his we from it, I hope I at least get an invite to the wedding.” With Valentineaposs Day fast approaching back in , Mark had chosen to take drastic action in his hunt for a partner. He bought the m high and m wide billboard to advertise himself in Manchester city centre and had  applicants in just  hours. Speaking of the unusual stunt, Mark said he had over , requests and did eventually end up in a relationship. However, he said he didnapost find love from the ad. Now in a new relationship with someone he met in person, he admits he might approach it dferently in hindsight – especially as his new girlfriend told him she saw the ad but would never have considered applying because she thought he looked too desperate. Mark, who is the founder ofChristmastrees , said: “I don’t regret doing the billboard, but it comes with challenges and pressures that I hadn’t considered or foreseen.“The media attention and ‘going viral’ is a double-edged sword, it’s helpful for getting the word out, but on the other hand it was incredibly overwhelming. “It all became a little too much, to the point where, looking back, I probably wasn’t in the right frame of mind to be dating just after I did the billboard. “There are other pressures too, you can’t date everyone – or marry everyone, in Malik’s case – so you’re going to reject a lot of people. I was conscious of the fact that it takes courage to apply to date someone from a billboard ad, and I didn’t want anyone to come away from it feeling rejected or disappointed.  “Then there’s the other additional pressure of, whatI put up this billboard, and then I still don’t find someone ” Two years on, Mark also has some advice for what he thinks others need to do to make something like this successful. Details are very important, even down to the font. He added: “Use comic sans, it is the font of love, so I was disappointed to see that Malik hadn’t used it. “Be specic in what you are looking for. I didn’t specy my sexuality , and at one point half my applications were from men. “Have a thick skin, the internet can be a harsh place so be prepared to be called all sorts of things.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON LoveMarriageViralSexuality" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: five lockdown demands experts curb
story: Five lockdown demands from experts to curb Omicrons overwhelming riseThe Independent Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesgroup says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitorsIndie Sage are making further recommendations to help curb the spread of the Omicron iant Image: Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan  group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsFive measures should come into force to slow the spread of the Omicron Covid- iant, the Independent Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesgroup has urged.In a briefing today, Independent Sage they should be brought in to last at least until the end of February.These measures include working from home where possible, providing CO monitors and ensuring adequate ventilation in all classrooms, revising the list of symptoms of Covid- to reflect those associated with Omicron, requiring people to wear high-quality masksin indoor public spaces and providing them for free, and to provide adequate sick pay for those unwell with Covid.Got a story  Email webnews@mirror  The group of about  scientists work together to provide independent scientic advice on the Covid- pandemic. Their recommendations comes as England has reported more than three million Covid cases since December  - with more than one million logged just last week alone.The independent scientists are warning that these alarming figures are almost certainly an underestimate andmeasures were brought in last month it could have helped avert the current NHS crisis.Furthermore, ONS data published this week has revealed that an estimated .million people in the UK - or two per cent of the population - are experiencing long Covid as of December . Other worrying figures have also found that hospitalisations in children under  have trebled since the start of December.Todayaposs announcement from Sage comes as Boris Johnson also confirmed that no further lockdown restrictions would be introduced, but Plan B measures would remain in place for a further three weeks.  Five measures recommended by SAGE  Working from home where possible until the end of February Those in England who can work from home are recommended to, according to current Plan B measures that came into force on December . Plan B measures are still in place and will next be reviewed on January . Mr Johnson told MPs on Wednesday: In response to the latest data the cabinet agreed this morning that we should stick with Plan B for another three weeks with a further review before the regulations expire on  January. This means it could possibly be scrapped by the end of the monththey are not extended again.  Providing CO monitors and ensuring adequate ventilation air filtration in all classrooms This week it was reported that schools are teetering on the edge as more than a third of heads reported staff absence levels of over  per cent due to Covid on the first day of term. A snap survey by the NAHT union found the majorityhad pupils absent due to Covid, while nearly a thirdreported over  per cent of children were out of class because of the virus. In a bid to help stop the spread of Covid- in schools, the Department of Education announced plans to deliver , CO monitors to all state schools.  A poll by the NASUWT teachers union this week foundof the nearly , teachers who responded said they do not have access to a CO monitor in their classroom. From January , the government has said face coverings are recommended in schools with pupils in year  and above. It goes on to say they should be worn in most classrooms, and by pupils, students, staff and adult visitors when moving around buildings.  Revising the list of symptoms of Covid- The NHS website still lists the main symptoms of Covid as a fever, a new cough and the loss of taste or smell. The symptoms that have been associated with the Omicron iant have dfered with many reporting a runny nose, headache, fatigue, sneezing and a sore throat. Professor Tim Spector, the scientist behind symptom tracker app Zoe, described the symptoms of Omicron as being more similar to that of a common cold. This means itaposs much easier to missyouaposre infected with Omicron, with Prof. Spector warning anyone with cold-like symptoms to take a Covid test to make sure.   Requiring high-quality masks for indoor public spaces New rules brought into force last month required anyone aged  or over to wear a face mask to enter a wide range of indoor venues including public transport. FFP masks are considered to be highly-effective face coverings. Many countries in Europe, including Austria, require these specic masks to be worn in public spaces. Independent Sage is recommending the UK government follows suit and requires this specic grade of mask for indoor public spaces as well as providing them for free to households.  Adequate sick pay for those unwell with Covid- From December,  sick pay rules wee being temporarily relaxed to help free up GPs for the booster rollout, meaning workers won’t need to see their doctorthey are unwell over the Christmas period. Under previous rules, workers who are unwell need to show their employer a GP-signed sick note after seven days to receive statutory sick pay or benefit payments. However, this was relaxed to  days – meaning you won’t need proof until almost a month after you fall ill. Anyone in work who goes off sick wonapost be asked for one until after  days of sickness, which includes non-working days. However, this rule is currently in place until January , . After that, the rules willto the normal seven day period. title: hairdressers flat frozen time after
story: Hairdressers flat is frozen in time after she transformed it into a s havenThe incredible property has been a labour of love for the mum of one, who was determined to turn her home into a mid-century inspired masterpiece, filled with colourHer flat is frozen in time Image: @MyRetroDecorByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsTake a look around this time capsule flat that takes you back to the Sevenies and gawp at the colourful interior. The one-bedroom flat in Manchester was designed by hairdresser Becky Morris, , who was keen to turn her pad into a groovy home. Her love of colour and eclectic patterns is clear -as she tried to show off the psychedelic interior of the s without going overboard.Becky Morris transformed her small one bed flat into a mid-century inspired masterpiece - and shares her interior journey on Instagram at @myretrodecor.She said: Iaposm obsessed with colour as I love how it can set the tone and mood of a room. Warm bright colours make me feel good, that’s why I fill my house with them, especially in the winter. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here I’m completely drawn to oranges and yellows, teak woods and bold clashing patterns and the ’s was a great era for that, I think that’s why my passion first arose. The ’s were a great era not just for interiors but also for music, fashion, furniture and architecture. I love reading books on these subjects and watching documentaries to better my knowledge of them, and that was my starting point.  I started to put together my ideas on what I wanted and also what I could do with the space I have here at home. I’m always on the lookout for inspiration. A recent documentary I watched was ‘Eames: The Architect and The Painter’ which I’d highly recommend for anyone interested in midcentury design. It’s already sparked a few new ideas for the future! And she advises checking out chain furniture shops alongside vintage and charity shops - with some of her homeware purchased from IKEA.  Also, I like to mix new with old. Quite a lot of modern retailers love to throwback to classic designs or put their modern spin on things. IKEA is great at creating mid-century replicas. Soyouaposre looking for a specic look, don’t discount modern shops you’d be surprised at what they have to offer, added Becky. Talking about how to recreate her groovy getaway, the mum of one says people shouldnapost be afraid of clashing patterns. She said: When it comes to recreating s and s interiors, I think wallpaper is the first thing to go for. I’ve changed the wallpaper in my apartment more times than I can remember- I’m a bit of a wallpaper addict. Iaposve never been shy of going for bold colours and patterns, and clashing, contrasting colours are always good when going for a ’s vibe. “Becky’s sense of style is out of this world. The level of detail is truly outstanding” says Alex Whitecroft, Head of Design atI Want Wallpaper.From her bold use of coordinated colours and bold patterns to her eye for mid-century furniture, her home showcases all of the key elements that made s interior design such a force and one that inspires even today. Itaposs a great example of the power of interior design. It can evoke feelings of wonder and nostalgia and, as Becky has shown us, even make us feel like we’ve travelled through time.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON IkeaLoveAccessoriesproperty news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: huge 100 tonne rock chunk
story: Huge -tonne rock chunk crashes off  million-year-old clf after stormy weatherIncredible pictures from Portland Bill on Dorsets Jurassic Coast have shown the extent of the dramatic clf fallA -tonne chunk of rock has crashed into the sea at Portland Bill on Dorsets Jurassic Coast Image: Jeffrey Webb BNPSByCorey RossKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA huge chunk of rock weighing around  tonnes has broken off from a  million-year-old clf, smashing into the waves below. Incredible pictures from Portland Bill on Dorsetaposs Jurassic Coast show the exposed clfside after the dramatic event.The break comes after recent stormy weather, with locals commenting they could see the rock beginning to crack under the pressure from the incoming winds.Strong waves whipped up by south westerly winds have crashed against the base of the clf, ultimately causing the massive block of rock to break off. Portland resident Jeffrey Webb noticed the dramatic fall walking his dog on Wednesday night.  He ed with his camera on Thursday to capture it the aftermath. The fall happened about ft from Red Crane, a fishermanaposs crane erected on a disused stone loading quay which is an ancient monument, and the whole area is popular with walkers and visitors. Marcus Dampier-Smith, who owns an old coastguard cottage on Portland Bill, said: This chunk of rock has been marked for falling for a while now.  Weaposve seen the large cracks running through it and knew it was only a matter of time. Weaposre lucky here that we have relatively little erosion in comparison to further along the Jurassic coast. But when chunks go here, they tend to go big. People love Portland Bill and walking over the rocks, but should pay attention to cracks and keep back from the edges. People do take risks. A similar rock fall happened further along the Portland coast just over a year ago and in  Pom Pom rock, an ancient rock stack on Portland that weighed hundreds of tonnes, was destroyed by high seas in a storm.  The whitbed limestone is a hard rock but has natural fissures which the weather erodes. Dane Gould, from Portland Bill Coastguard team said: The rock falls we get are not as big as some further along the coast, but they look very dramatic because the rock falls away in big chunks. This one is about  tonnes. The stone has natural fissures through it and the weather and waves have got in between the cracks and undermined it, gradually working it loose and then a big wave has got the pressure around the stone and pulled it away. A big wave can have a lot of power, people underestimate it. It could be dangerousyou walk on the wrong part, because it could fall away at any time. news uk-news kate-middleton-prepared-george-future-"Sweet moment between Prince George and Kate Middleton at Euros finalByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments He may only be eight years old - but Prince Georgeaposs future has already been mapped out for him.Itaposs his destiny to one day be King and play a pivotal role in ensuring the future of the monarchy.And according to one royal expert, his mum the Duchess of Cambridge has already got a plan for Georgeaposs journey into a royal le - and she taught him one vital lesson on duty last year. Last July, George made a rare public appearance with Kate and his dad Prince William in the royal box at Wembley to watch England take on Italy in the final of the Euros. Cameras caught the young prince celebrating wildly with his parents when England went ahead early in the match.And at the end of the game, after England lost on penalties, his forlorn face summed up the heartbreak of the nation.At the game, George wore a grown-up suit that mirrored his dads, leading fans to ask why he wasnapost allowed to wear an England shirt like other youngsters of his age.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. But according to royal author Duncan Larcombe, it was Kate who insisted on the suit - and for a very good reason.He told OK! : William was apparently keen on the idea [of wearing a football shirt], but it was Kate, the former commoner, who said no. She was showing George that being ’on duty’ requires a dferent approach… he has to learn to don the royal armour.“That doesn’t mean hiding his personality or feelings though – so George was encouraged to leap up and celebrate England scoring, to roar and wave and hug his mum and dad like any normal lad. And even to shed a tear when it all ended in heartbreak.  “George is only just beginning to understand his destiny, but Kate has got the journey planned.”Of course, George and Kateaposs other two children Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis will be gearing up for Sunday, when their mum celebrates her milestone th birthday.It is believed that Kate is in for a special day of low-key celebrations surrounded by her family and friends.But according to one royal expert, she could be in for a very big birthday party that will be thrown by the Queen herself.Royal author Ingrid Seward says she is absolutely certain that the monarch will eventually throw Kate a big birthday bash.And it could be a joint party with William, who also turns  in June after the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations. Ingrid told True Royalty TVaposs The Royal Beat: I think it will be low key this weekend, and then later in the year - probably after the platinum jubilee celebrations are over - she and William, whose birthday is on June st, will have a joint party and really celebrate then.Iaposm absolutely certain the Queen will throw a bash for them. news uk-news little-known-dog-laws-catch-"UK dog laws every owner should know aboutByCatherine Swan:,  Jan | commentsThere are a lot of responsibilities that come with being a dog owner. As well as making sure they get the right food, plenty of exercise and lots of attention, there are also things that owners must learn to avoid getting on the wrong side of the law. While most owners know that failing to pick up their dogaposs mess while out on a walk can result in a fine, there are several lesser-known rules around walking and driving with dogs which could see even the most careful owners caught out. Here’s what every dog owner needs to know to avoid getting caught out and possibly hit with hefty fines. ID tagsThe first thing that owners need to bear in mind concernsidentity tags for dogswhen out in public.Failing to put a tag on your dog with your details on it could land you a fine, or even jail time. The Control of Dogs Order  law for England and Scotland says that a dog must wear a tag with their owner’s name and address on it. This means thatdogs are caught not wearing a proper identication tag, their owners are considered guilty of an offence against the Animal Health Act of . Owners could subsequently be hit with what was formerly a level  fine, which was capped at a maximum of £, until . However, the cap has since been scrapped, which means that anyone convicted could receive an unlimited fine or even a six-month prison sentence in the worst case scenario - although the fines handed out are likely to be much lower.  Lead walkingDog owners should also be aware of the laws in their area around letting dogs walk off lead.Although taking your dog off their lead is permitted in most UK parks, there are some spots where it’s illegal - and owners who fall foul could be fined up to £,. Local authorities can issue a Public Spaces Protection Order or Dog Control Order, which means that dogs must be kept on a lead in certain spaces - or in some cases, they prevent dogs from being allowed in the area altogether. Areas such as beaches, sport pitches and flower beds are the most common places that are off-limits to dogs, while they often have to be kept on leads near play areas and bodies of water. Owners should keep a lookout for signs in these areas alerting them to the rules concerning their dogs.  Similarly,another little-known lawabout where dogs are allowed off lead is likely to catch unaware owners out. The Road Traffic Act  says that it’s a criminal offence for a dog to be on a ‘designated road’they’re not on a lead.To help keep both dogs and drivers safe, the law requires dogs to be kept on a lead while they’re crossing a road, and also while walking on a pavement beside a busy road to prevent them from darting out into traffic.Even owners of the most well-behaved dogs could see themselves facing a staggering fine of up to £, and six months in prisontheir failure to obey the law results in a road accident, according toSelect Car Leasing . DrivingIf you are driving somewhere with your dog rather than walking them, there are yetmore rules to be aware of .Failing to make sure that your pet is properly secured in your car is a breach of the Highway Code, and could see owners hit with a fine of up to £, for careless driving. While the code isn’t specic about where dogs should be placed in the car, it’s recommended that they sit in the backseat or boot for safety reasons.Car dealer Peter Vardy also warns driversagainst letting their dog stick their head out of the window, which could be a sign that your dog isn’t secured properly in the car - as well as distracting others on the road.Although it’s not set out in law that dogs shouldn’t stick their head out of the window, drivers still risk being pulled over for ‘driving without due care and attention’, which could result in a fine and points on your licence. title: man amazed delivery letter life
story: Man amazed at delivery of letter with his le story on envelope in place of addressMusician Feargan Lynn had a surprise on Thursday when a thin white letter popped through the letterbox with ten lines of text rather than the usual addressFeargal applauded Royal Mail for tracking him down Image: twitter weefeargal   Belfast liveBySophie McLaughlin:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA man has shared his amazement after a letter arrived at his home with a description of who he was, rather than an address. Musician Feargan Lynn had a surprise on Thursday when a thin white letter popped through the letterbox with ten lines of text rather than the usual address.Sharing the hilarious moment on Twitter, Feargal gave Royal Mail a shout out, congratulating the mail deliverer for tracking him down.“Hearty applause to @RoyalMail Cushendall and Ballymena for being able to deliver this letter to me today got a much needed laugh!” he wrote. “They had a first name, the village where I grew up and half the postcode.. the rest is more like my le story!” In typical Northern Ireland fashion, likened to your mother trying to describe someone in the middle of a story, Feargal felt like he was reading his le on the page.  The full description said: “Feargal, Lives across the road from the Spar, his ma and da used to own it, his mother was Mary and Da Joseph, moved to Waterfoot after he got married, plays guitar and used to run discos in the parochial hall and the hotel in the s. “Friends with the fella runs the butchers in Waterfoot too.”Speaking toBelfast Live , the Cushendall man said he was “more than amazed at the reaction” to his post which has over K likes on Twitter so far.Feargal said: “I decided last year to write handwritten letters after a singer   songwriter friend Hannah Scott wrote a song called The Letter about keeping the art of letter writing alive. “I wrote to a friend over Christmas whom I’d known all my le from summer holidays and I didn’t put my address on the letter - this was her response. “It was like seeing my le on an envelope.” Feargal’s discos in both Waterfoot and Cushendall were attended and loved by many in the community - with the letter bringing a warming sense of nostalgia to his followers on Thursday. title: meghan markles lawyer says damaging
story: Meghan Markle’s lawyer says bullying allegations do not match my experience of herMeghan Markles lawyer, Jenny Afia, has said that claims of bullying have been used "very casually" as she discussed allegations that the Duchess mistreated palace staff, when speaking with the BBCs Amol Rajan" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Prince-Harry-and-Princess-Megan-visit-NYC.jpg" width"" "" Prince Harry and Meghan Markle visit the One World Observatory in New York Image: Anadolu Agency via Getty ImagesByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMeghan Markle’s lawyer has said allegations of bullying made against Meghan do not match my experience of her. Jenny Afia, speaking during a BBC podcast, said the Duchess of Sussex denied the claims but she did not want to negate anyoneaposs personal experiences. Speaking to Amol Rajan, the Schillings law firm solicitor spoke out about reports Meghanaposs behaviour had led to an internal review. Miss Afia said that the word “bullying” was a “very very damaging term … particularly for career woman.” She added the Duchess “absolutely denies” any such accusations. Miss Afia told the podcast, called Harry, Meghan and the Media: “I think the first thing is to be really clear about what bullying is because the term gets used very, very casually.“My daughter called me a bully last week when I asked her to brush her teeth – sheaposs seven years old. “So the term is used very freely and itaposs a very, very damaging term as we know, particularly I think for career women.” She was speaking on a new podcast series based off of Mr Rajan’s BBC documentary which examined the relationship between the royal family and media.  Mr Rajan’s podcast was thought to have been delayed after the documentary emerged in November. This was because of tensions of how the royals would react to the show. A two-minute trailer emerged for the podcast on BBC Sounds in November, with the first episode originally due later that month. However, the corporation decided to delay its release. Ms Afia added: “What bullying actually means is improperly using power repeatedly and deliberately to hurt someone, physically or emotionally. The Duchess of Sussex absolutely denies ever doing that. “Knowing her as I do I canapost believe she would ever do that. I wasnapost there at the time but it doesnapost match my experience of her at all and Iaposve seen her at very, very stressful times. “That story is absolutely untrue that she is a bully. That said, she wouldnapost want to negate anyoneaposs personal experiences.” Palace aides announced in March last year that they had decided to launch an internal inquiry into claims that Meghan’s behaviour drove two of her personal assistants to quit and “undermined the confidence” of a third.  This comes as the Mail on Sunday will pay only £ in damages to Meghan after it published a private letter she had sent to her father. The nominal sum confirmed that the paper, as well as its associated website MailOnline, accepted defeat in the long running case and will not be taking it to the Court of Appeal. The paper will also pay an unspecied amount of money for the separate case of infringing Meghan’sby publishing signicant parts of the letter. title: mums mistake over 115 charge
story: Mum mortied at £ charge for € bottle of Ryanair prosecco before realising mistakeDawn Paisley Mills, from Toxteth, believed that she had been charged £ for € bottle of prosecco on a Ryanair flight and spent  months trying to get a refundA woman thought she had been charged £ for a bottle of proseccoByDan HaygarthTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA Ryanair passenger thought she had been charged £ for a € bottle of prosecco on a flight to Portugal and spent  months trying to get a refund before realising she had made a mistake. Dawn Paisley Mills, a mum-of-five from Toxteth, bought a bottle of Mionetto Prosecco on a Ryanair flight from Liverpool to Faro on July , , and was shocked when she read what she thought was the price.She said the bottle, a gt for her boyfriend, should have cost €, but when she ed from her flight she noticed a charge of £ from Ryanair on her bank statement, reported the Liverpool Echo.Dawn spent the next  months sending numerous complaints and requests for a refund to Ryanair - but it turned out the £ was the cost for herflight to Manchester six days later and not the bottle of prosecco. “I don’t usually buy anything on flights but a couple sitting next to me had bought the bottle and it was quite pretty and it was tiny, said Dawn.  “So I called them over so I could buy it as a present for my boyfriend. I didn’t think anything of it. I wanted to pay with cash but they said they were only taking cards, so I put my card in and paid.“I filmed myself with the bottle of wine to put on Facebook to let my friends know that I was on the flight. I was saying ‘look, I’ve bought this wine as a gt’.“I got home five days later and went into my bank account and saw I had been charged £. I was asking my bank to get the money back and they were telling me to give them all the evidence, so I sent them all the paperwork, the pictures of me. My bank askedI had a receipt, but at some point I cleared my bag out - you’re not going to keep a receipt you think is for €.”  Dawn said she made many attempts to get a refund, but struggled to get any response from Ryanairaposs automated customer service system. She said: “When you phone them, you don’t speak to people. They’re all automated calls and every time you ring through, this call puts you onto another automated voice which brings you back to the beginning, so you don’t get to speak to anybody. “Then they tell you to go online and when you go online, they’ve got these ‘chatbots’. You’re talking to these chatbots, trying to tell them what’s happened and then the chatbot says ‘we’ve not got enough information’ and then it cuts you off.” It wasnapost until last Wednesday, January , that she actually found the truth about what had happened. Dawn explained the payment for the bottle of wine had not shown up on her bank statement, which led to her confusion - and it likely means she got the bottle for free, as the card machines on the flight had been faulty. title: onlyfans model says earns 30000
story: OnlyFans model says he earns £, a month posing with his dad - who only gets £Jake Herbert was earning a tidy £, on his OnlyFans account - but that more than tripled after getting his dad involved. Despite his huge earnings he only gives his dad £Jake Herbert earns a tidy £, a month on OnlyFans after enlisting his dad Image: @jakeherbettBySophie FosterLestyle  Travel ReporterKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A man is earning up to £, with his OnlyFans account, but thereaposs a twist - he poses for raunchy pictures with his dad. Jake Herbert only started x-rated account in a bid to get some extra cast but was soon earning up to £, every month with just pictures of him. The -year-old had already worked as a naked butler in Ibiza and was used to getting his kit off, and after signing up requests for content came pouring in, the Daily Star reports. OnlyFans allows content creators to share naked images and videos with their fans who pay a monthly amount to access the snaps.  Creators can also interact with their fans to get tips, make paid requests and even receive gts. The lad told the BBC : I was like, ‘Alright then, how much ’ And they actually started putting some not bad figures on.” Jake was earning between £, and £, a year for the cheeky content, but his account went viral after he got his dad involved.But, things hotted up and the money came flooding in when Jake got his dad involved. The young lad started by posting some topless photos of himself and his father after they visited the gym and it “just went mental”.  Jake added: I knew to get to the next level I’d have to do something that would really get everyone talking. At the beginning he was like, ‘How are we making so much money ’ He was getting bits of banter from where he was working and he was umming and ahhing about it, and I was like, ‘Dad, we just need to make this money. It’s not that we’re actually doing anything’. The -year-old persuaded his dad to get on board and now makes up to £, a month taking his annual income up to around £,. But, he doesn’t vy up the cash equally and instead gives his dad the odd £.  He noted: I know I should [pay him more], but I started the thing. It’s my page and I built it up. Jake claims he doesn’t care what people think about his posts because he knew it would lead to a big payout and get him more subscribers.
